awd_titl_txt: Star formation and molecular cloud structure at low metallicity
awd_abstract_narration:
New stars are continuously forming in galaxies like the Milky Way. Galaxies begin as mostly hydrogen atoms, but nuclear fusion inside of stars produces heavier atoms. These atoms, like carbon and oxygen, are spewed out by dying stars, changing the chemistry of the space between the stars. The process begins again with the formation of new giant clouds of gas, which become cold and dense enough that atoms bond together to form molecules. New molecular clouds begin to form the next generations of stars. 

These heavy atoms from the first generation of stars are caught up in a molecular cloud and absorb ultraviolet light from nearby stars. The absorption helps to protect the fragile molecules from being broken apart, again changing the chemistry of the clouds.  The investigator seeks to understand these chemical processes by comparison of the Milky Way to the chemistry in nearby dwarf irregular galaxies.  These small galaxies have much less of the heavy atoms compared to spiral galaxies like the Milky Way. As a result, the outer parts of molecular clouds in those dwarf galaxies are destroyed, leaving smaller molecular clouds than are found in spiral galaxies. 

The investigator is studying the structure of molecular clouds in tiny dwarf galaxies. The investigator seeks to understand the consequences on star formation in dwarf galaxies due to the differences in molecular abundance.  Stars are forming in dwarf galaxies, and the investigator plans additional observations to understand the nature of the gas in these galaxies. The answers to these questions will help us to understand star formation in the early universe, before heavy atoms were formed. 

The investigator leads the Lowell Observatory Native American Astronomy Outreach Program, which pairs astronomers with 4th-8th grade teachers in the Navajo and Hopi Nations.  The program holds tri-annual teacher workshops that introduce teachers to classroom activities enhancing their understanding of astronomy.  The collaborators create culturally responsive curriculum that enables Native students to see themselves as scientists and addresses the tribal and educational standards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stars in galaxies form out of molecular clouds, but the structure of these clouds changes drastically at metallicities lower than in the Milky Way. Far-ultraviolet photons from stars disrupt the molecules in an outer shell of the cloud. The lower the metallicity, the deeper the FUV photons can penetrate and the thicker the shell is likely to become, resulting in a smaller molecular core. Hunter and her collaborators for the first time imaged the molecular cores and surrounding shell in a star-forming region at 13% of the metallicity of the sun. They found tiny molecular CO cores inside a thick shell. These measurements were achieved in WLM, a Local Group dwarf irregular galaxy.  However, the map of the molecular cores compared to the FUV knots of hot young stars suggests that we may not understand what gas the stars are actually forming from.

This project was a multi-wavelength, in-depth study of the molecular gas and star formation in WLM for which the team has data that reveal the molecular cores, stellar populations, and atomic hydrogen gas. These data were used to address the following questions: 1) What are the galactic environments in which star-forming clouds form at low metallicity? 2) How does "dark" gas, molecular gas that is not seen directly but is inferred from dust and hydrogen gas emission, relate to molecular cloud cores and to star formation? 3) Is star formation taking place in the extreme conditions of outer stellar disks? 4) What effect does the different structure of molecular clouds have on the star formation products in low metallicity galaxies? Most of this work was carried out by graduate student Haylee Archer.

Archer studied the environments in which molecular cloud cores formed in WLM. She used the catalog of molecular cores and characterized the galactic environments in which these cores formed. She grouped the cores together based on proximity to each other and strong FUV emission, examined properties of the star-forming region enveloping the cores and the surrounding environment where the cores formed. She found that high hydrogen surface density does not necessarily correspond to higher total molecular mass, but regions with higher molecular mass have higher hydrogen surface densities. She also found that the cores in star-forming regions spanning a wide range of ages show no correlation between age and molecular core mass, suggesting that the tiny size of the cores is not due to fragmentation of the clouds with age. The presence of molecular cores in a variety of different local environments, along with the similar properties between star-forming regions with and without molecular cores, led her to conclude that there are no obvious environmental characteristics that drive the formation of these cores.

Hunter and collaborators completed a study of the stellar, gaseous, and young stellar disks in a sample of nearby dwarf irregulars. From the star formation activity they estimated the molecular fraction as a function of radius for each galaxy by converting the FUV to a molecular surface density using conventional calibrations. The resulting molecular fractions imply the presence of a significant amount of undetected "dark" molecular gas.

Despite actively forming stars, the early stages of star formation in dwarf galaxies is not well understood. Archer examined the relationship between early star formation and molecular clouds in WLM using JWST images. She identified sources that are bright at 2.5 microns and which are likely embedded young star clusters. She found that objects near molecular cores are also coincident with Spitzer 8 micron sources, suggesting that they are in fact embedded young star clusters.

Archer obtained images of a large star-forming region in WLM with the Hubble Space Telescope at a wide range of wavelengths. These high resolution data combined with the map of molecular clouds and atomic hydrogen gas will be analyzed in 2024 to put together a complete picture of the structure of a large star forming region at low metallicity. She will measure the mass, age, and extinction towards the massive stars in the regions, calculate the ionized gas mass, constrain the cloud boundaries, and map the extinction due to dust. These will enable her to map the presence of "dark" molecular gas and characterize the stars that have formed in the region.
